PLAY.TITLE: The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Sampson and Gregory, with Swords and Bucklers, of the House of Capulet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sampson.
SPEECH.LINE: Gregory: A my word wee'l not carry coales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: No, for then we ſhould be Colliars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: I mean, if we be in choller, wee'l draw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: I, While you liue, draw your necke out o'th Collar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſtrike quickly, being mou’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: But thou art not quickly mou’d to ſtrike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: A dog of the house of Mountague, moues me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: To moue, is to ſtir: and to be valiant, is to ſtand:
Therefore, if thou art mou’d, thou runst away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: A dogge of that house ſhall moue me to ſtand.
I will take the wall of any Man or Maid of Mountagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhewes thee a weake ſlaue, for the wea-kest goes to the wall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: True, and therefore women being the weaker Veſſels, are euer thrust to the wall: therefore I will push Mountagues men from the wall, and thrust his Maides to the wall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: The Quarrell is betweene our Masters, and vs their men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis all one, I will ſhew my ſelfe a tyrant: when
I haue fought with the men, I will bee ciuill with the
Maids, and cut off their heads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: The heads of the Maids?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sam.
SPEECH.LINE: I, the heads of the Maids, or their Maiden-heads,
Take it in what ſence thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: They must take it ſence, that feele it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: Me they ſhall feele while I am able to ſtand:
And ‘tis knowne I am a pretty peece of flesh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well thou art not Fish: If thou had'st, thou had'st beene poore Iohn. Draw thy Toole, here comes of the House of the Mountagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sam.
SPEECH.LINE: My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I wil back thee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: How? Turne thy backe, and run.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sam.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: No marry: I feare thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sam.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs take the Law of our ſides: let them begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gr.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil frown as I paſſe by, & let the[m] take it as they list

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sam.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, as they dare. I wil bite my Thumb at them, which is a disgrace to them, if they beare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abra.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you bite your Thumbe at vs ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: I do bite my Thumbe, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abra.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you bite your Thumb at vs, ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sam.
SPEECH.LINE: Is the Law of our ſide, if I ſay I?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sam.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, I do not bite my Thumbe at you ſir: but
I bite my Thumbe ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Greg.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you quarrell ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abra.
SPEECH.LINE: Quarrell ſir? no ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sam.
SPEECH.LINE: If you do ſir, I am for you, I ſerue as good a man as you

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abra.
SPEECH.LINE: No better?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gr.
SPEECH.LINE: Say better: here comes one of my masters kinsmen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abra.
SPEECH.LINE: You Lye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Samp.
SPEECH.LINE: Draw if you be men. Gregory, remember thy washing blow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Part Fooles, put vp your Swords, you know not what you do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tyb.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou drawne, among these heartleſſe
Hindes? Turne thee Benuolio, looke vpon thy death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: I do but keepe the peace, put vp thy Sword,
Or manage it to part these men with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tyb.
SPEECH.LINE: What draw, and talke of peace? I hate the word
As I hate hell, all Mountagues, and thee:
Haue at thee Coward.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter three or foure Citizens with Clubs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Offi.
SPEECH.LINE: Clubs, Bils, and Partisons, ſtrike, beat them down
Downe with the Capulets, downe with the Mountagues.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter old Capulet in his Gowne, and his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: What noise is this? Giue me my long Sword ho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wife.
SPEECH.LINE: A crutch, a crutch: why call you for a Sword?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: My Sword I ſay: Old Mountague is come,
And flourishes his Blade in ſpight of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moun.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou villaine Capulet. Hold me not, let me go

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Wife.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt not ſtir a foote to ſeeke a Fœ.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Prince Eskales, with his Traine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Rebellious Subiects, Enemies to peace,
Prophaners of this Neighbor-stained Steele,
Will they not heare? What hœ, you Men, you Beasts,
That quench the fire of your pernitious Rage,
With purple Fountaines iſſuing from your Veines:
On paine of Torture, from those bloody hands
Throw your mistemper’d Weapons to the ground,
And heare the Sentence of your mooued Prince.
Three ciuill Broyles, bred of an Ayery word,
By thee old Capulet and Mountague,
Haue thrice disturb’d the quiet of our ſtreets,
And made Verona's ancient Citizens
Cast by their Graue beseeming Ornaments,
To wield old Partizans, in hands as old,
Cankred with peace, to part your Cankred hate,
If euer you disturbe our ſtreets againe,
Your liues ſhall pay the forfeit of the peace.
For this time all the rest depart away:
You Capulet ſhall goe along with me,
And Mountague come you this afternoone,
To know our Fathers pleasure in this case:
To old Free-towne, our common iudgement place:
Once more on paine of death, all men depart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moun.
SPEECH.LINE: Who ſet this auncient quarrell new abroach?
Speake Nephew, were you by, when it began:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere were the ſeruants of your aduersarie,
And yours close fighting ere I did approach,
I drew to part them, in the instant came
The fiery Tibalt, with his ſword prepar’d,
Which as he breath’d defiance to my eares,
He ſwong about his head, and cut the windes,
Who nothing hurt withall, hist him in ſcorne.
While we were enterchanging thrusts and blowes,
Came more and more, and fought on part and part,
Till the Prince came, who parted either part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wife.
SPEECH.LINE: O where is Romeo, ſaw you him to day?
Right glad am I, he was not at this fray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, an houre before the worshipt Sun
Peer’d forth the golden window of the East,
A troubled mind draue me to walke abroad,
Where vnderneath the groue of Sycamour,
That West-ward rooteth from this City ſide:
So earely walking did I ſee your Sonne:
Towards him I made, but he was ware of me,
And ſtole into the couert of the wood,
I measuring his affections by my owne,
Which then mo’t ſought, wher mo’t might not be found:
Being one too many by my weary ſelfe,
Pursued my Honour, not pursuing his
And gladly ſhunn’d, who gladly fled from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mount.
SPEECH.LINE: Many a morning hath he there beene ſeene,
With teares augmenting the fresh mornings deaw,
Adding to cloudes, more cloudes with his deepe ſighes,
But all ſo ſoone as the all-cheering Sunne,
Should in the farthest East begin to draw
The ſhadie Curtaines from Auroras bed,
Away from light ſteales home my heauy Sonne,
And priuate in his Chamber pennes himselfe,
Shuts vp his windowes, lockes faire day-light out,
And makes himselfe an artificiall night:
Blacke and portendous must this humour proue,
Vnleſſe good counsell may the cause remoue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: My Noble Vncle doe you know the cause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moun.
SPEECH.LINE: I neither know it, nor can learne of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you importun’d him by any meanes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moun.
SPEECH.LINE: Both by my ſelfe and many other Friends,
But he his owne affections counseller,
Is to himselfe (I will not ſay how true)
But to himselfe ſo ſecret and ſo close,
So farre from ſounding and discouery,
As is the bud bit with an enuious worme,
Ere he can ſpread his ſweete leaues to the ayre,
Or dedicate his beauty to the ſame.
Could we but learne from whence his ſorrowes grow,
We would as willingly giue cure, as know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: See where he comes, ſo please you ſtep aside,
Ile know his greeuance, or be much denide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moun.
SPEECH.LINE: I would thou wert ſo happy by thy ſtay,
To heare true ſhrift. Come Madam let's away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow Cousin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Is the day ſo young?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: But new ſtrooke nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Aye me, ſad houres ſeeme long:
Was that my Father that went hence ſo fast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: It was: what ſadnes lengthens Romeo's houres?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: Not hauing that, which hauing, makes them ſhort

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: In loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Romeo.
SPEECH.LINE: Out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Of loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Out of her fauour where I am in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas that loue ſo gentle in his view,
Should be ſo tyrannous and rough in proofe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas that loue, whose view is muffled ſtill,
Should without eyes, ſee path-wayes to his will:
Where ſhall we dine? O me: what fray was heere?
Yet tell me not, for I haue heard it all:
Heere's much to do with hate, but more with loue:
Why then, O brawling loue, O louing hate,
O any thing, of nothing first created:
O heauie lightneſſe, ſerious vanity,
Mishapen Chaos of welseeming formes,
Feather of lead, bright ſmoake, cold fire, ſicke health,
Still waking ſleepe, that is not what it is:
This loue feele I, that feele no loue in this.
Doest thou not laugh?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: No Coze, I rather weepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Good heart, at what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: At thy good hearts oppreſſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſuch is loues transgreſſion.
Griefes of mine owne lie heauie in my breast,
Which thou wilt propagate to haue it preast
With more of thine, this loue that thou hast ſhowne,
Doth adde more griefe, to too much of mine owne.
Loue, is a ſmoake made with the fume of ſighes,
Being purg’d, a fire ſparkling in Louers eyes,
Being vext, a Sea nourisht with louing teares,
What is it else? a madneſſe, mo’t discreet,
A choking gall, and a preseruing ſweet:
Farewell my Coze.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft I will goe along.
And if you leaue me ſo, you do me wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut I haue lost my ſelfe, I am not here,
This is not Romeo, hee's ſome other where.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me in ſadneſſe, who is that you loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall I grone and tell thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Grone, why no: but ſadly tell me who.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſicke man in ſadneſſe makes his will:
A word ill vrg’d to one that is ſo ill:
In ſadneſſe Cozin, I do loue a woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: I aym’d ſo neare, when I ſuppos’d you lou’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: A right good marke man, and ſhee's faire I loue

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: A right faire marke, faire Coze, is ſoonest hit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Well in that hit you miſſe, ſheel not be hit
With Cupids arrow, ſhe hath Dians wit:
And in ſtrong proofe of chastity well arm’d:
From loues weake childish Bow, ſhe liues vncharm’d.
Shee will not ſtay the ſiege of louing tearmes,
Nor bid th’ encounter of aſſailing eyes.
Nor open her lap to Sainct-seducing Gold:
O ſhe is rich in beautie, onely poore,
That when ſhe dies, with beautie dies her ſtore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhe hath ſworne, that ſhe will ſtill liue chast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: She hath, and in that ſparing make huge wast?
For beauty ſteru’d with her ſeuerity,
Cuts beauty off from all posteritie.
She is too faire, too wise: wisely too faire,
To merit bliſſe by making me dispaire:
She hath forsworne to loue, and in that vow
Do I liue dead, that liue to tell it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Be rul’d by me, forget to thinke of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: O teach me how I ſhould forget to thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: By giuing liberty vnto thine eyes,
Examine other beauties,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis the way to cal hers (exquisit) in question more,
These happy maskes that kiſſe faire Ladies browes,
Being blacke, puts vs in mind they hide the faire:
He that is ſtrooken blind, cannot forget
The precious treasure of his eye-ſight lost:
Shew me a Mistreſſe that is paſſing faire,
What doth her beauty ſerue but as a note,
Where I may read who past that paſſing faire.
Farewell thou can'st not teach me to forget,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben
SPEECH.LINE: Ile pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Capulet, Countie Paris, and the Clowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Capu.
SPEECH.LINE: Mountague is bound as well as I,
In penalty alike, and ‘tis not hard I thinke,
For men ſo old as wee, to keepe the peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Of Honourable reckoning are you both,
And pittie ‘tis you liu’d at ods ſo long:
But now my Lord, what ſay you to my ſute?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Capu.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſaying ore what I haue ſaid before,
My Child is yet a ſtranger in the world,
Shee hath not ſeene the change of fourteene yeares,
Let two more Summers wither in their pride,
Ere we may thinke her ripe to be a Bride.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pari.
SPEECH.LINE: Younger then ſhe, are happy mothers made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Capu.
SPEECH.LINE: And too ſoone mar’d are those ſo early made:
Earth hath ſwallowed all my hopes but ſhe,
Shee's the hopefull Lady of my earth:
But woœ her gentle Paris, get her heart,
My will to her consent, is but a part,
And ſhee agree, within her ſcope of choise,
Lyes my consent, and faire according voice:
This night I hold an old accustom’d Feast,
Whereto I haue inuited many a Guest,
Such as I loue, and you among the ſtore,
One more, mo’t welcome makes my number more:
At my poore house, looke to behold this night,
Earth-treading ſtarres, that make darke heauen light,
Such comfort as do lusty young men feele,
When well apparrel’d Aprill on the heele
Of limping Winter treads, euen ſuch delight
Among fresh Fennell buds ſhall you this night
Inherit at my house: heare all, all ſee:
And like her mo’t, whose merit mo’t ſhall be:
Which one more veiw, of many, mine being one,
May ſtand in number, though in reckning none.
Come, goe with me: goe ſirrah trudge about,
Through faire Verona, find those persons out,
Whose names are written there, and to them ſay,
My house and welcome, on their pleasure ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Find them out whose names are written. Heere it is written, that the Shoo-maker ſhould meddle with his Yard, and the Tayler with his Last, the Fisher with his Pensill, and the Painter with his Nets. But I am ſent to find those persons whose names are writ, & can neuer find what names the writing person hath here writ (I must to the learned) in good time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut man, one fire burnes out anothers burning,
One paine is lesned by anothers anguish:
Turne giddie, and be holpe by backward turning:
One desparate greefe, cures with anothers languish:
Take thou ſome new infection to the eye,
And the rank poyson of the old wil die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Plantan leafe is excellent for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: For what I pray thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: For your broken ſhin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Romeo art thou mad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Not mad, but bound more then a mad man is:
Shut vp in prison, kept without my foode,
Whipt and tormented: and Godden good fellow,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Godgigoden, I pray ſir can you read?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I mine owne fortune in my miserie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Perhaps you haue learn’d it without booke:
But I pray can you read any thing you ſee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if I know the Letters and the Language.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Ye ſay honestly, rest you merry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay fellow, I can read. He reades the Letter. Seigneur Martino, and his wife and daughter: County An-selme and his beautious ſisters: the Lady widdow of Vtru-uio, Seigneur Placentio, and his louely Neeces: Mercutio and his brother Valentine: mine vncle Capulet his wife and daugh-ters: my faire Neece Rosaline, Liuia, Seigneur Valentio, & his Cosen Tybalt: Lucio and the liuely Helena. A faire aſſembly, whither ſhould they come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Whither? to ſupper?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: To our house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Whose house?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: My Maisters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed I ſhould haue askt you that before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Ile tell you without asking. My maister is the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of Mountagues I pray come and crush a cup of wine. Rest you merry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: At this ſame auncient Feast of Capulets
Sups the faire Rosaline, whom thou ſo loues:
With all the admired Beauties of Verona,
Go thither and with vnattainted eye,
Compare her face with ſome that I ſhall ſhow,
And I will make thee thinke thy Swan a Crow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: When the deuout religion of mine eye
Maintaines ſuch falshood, then turne teares to fire:
And these who often drown’d could neuer die,
Transparent Heretiques be burnt for liers.
One fairer then my loue: the all-seeing Sun
Nere ſaw her match, ſince first the world begun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, you ſaw her faire, none else being by,
Herselfe poys’d with herselfe in either eye:
But in that Christall ſcales, let there be waid,
Your Ladies loue against ſome other Maid
That I will ſhow you, ſhining at this Feast,
And ſhe ſhew ſcant ſhell, well, that now ſhewes best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile goe along, no ſuch ſight to be ſhowne,
But to reioyce in ſplendor of mine owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wife.
SPEECH.LINE: Nurse wher's my daughter? call her forth to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by my Maidenhead, at twelue yeare old
I bad her come, what Lamb: what Ladi-bird, God forbid,
Where's this Girle? what Iuliet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuliet.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, who calls?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuliet.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam I am heere, what is your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wife.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the matter: Nurse giue me leaue awhile, we must talke in ſecret. Nurse come backe againe, I haue re-membred me, thou'se heare our counsell. Thou knowest my daughter's of a prety age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith I can tell her age vnto an houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wife.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee's not fourteene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile lay fourteene of my teeth,
And yet to my teene be it ſpoken,
I haue but foure, ſhee's not fourteene.
How long is it now to Lammas tide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wife.
SPEECH.LINE: A fortnight and odde dayes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen or odde, of all daies in the yeare come Lammas Eue at night ſhall ſhe be fourteene. Susan & ſhe, God rest all Christian ſoules, were of an age. Well Susan is with God, ſhe was too good for me. But as I ſaid, on La-mas Eue at night ſhall ſhe be fourteene, that ſhall ſhe ma-rie, I remember it well. ‘Tis ſince the Earth-quake now eleuen yeares, and ſhe was wean’d I neuer ſhall forget it, of all the daies of the yeare, vpon that day: for I had then laid Worme-wood to my Dug ſitting in the Sunne vnder the Douehouse wall, my Lord and you were then at Mantua, nay I doe beare a braine. But as I ſaid, when it did tast the Worme-wood on the nipple of my Dugge, and felt it bitter, pretty foole, to ſee it teachie, and fall out with the Dugge, Shake quoth the Doue-house, 'twas no neede I trow to bid mee trudge, and ſince that time it is a eleuen yeares, for then ſhe could ſtand alone, nay bi'th’ roode ſhe could haue runne, & wadled all about: for euen the day before ſhe broke her brow, & then my Husband God be with his ſoule, a was a merrie man, tooke vp the Child, yea quoth hee, doest thou fall vpon thy face? thou wilt fall backeward when thou hast more wit, wilt thou not Iule? And by my holy-dam, the pretty wretch lefte crying, & ſaid I: to ſee now how a Iest ſhall come about. I warrant, & I ſhall liue a thousand yeares, I neuer ſhould forget it: wilt thou not Iule quoth he? and pretty foole it ſtinted, and ſaid I. Old La. Inough of this, I pray thee hold thy peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Madam, yet I cannot chuse but laugh, to thinke it ſhould leaue crying, & ſay I: and yet I warrant it had vpon it brow, a bumpe as big as a young Cockrels ſtone? A perilous knock, and it cryed bitterly. Yea quoth my husband, fall'st vpon thy face, thou wilt fall back-ward when thou commest to age: wilt thou not Iule? It ſtinted: and ſaid I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iule.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſtint thou too, I pray thee Nurse, ſay I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace I haue done: God marke thee too his grace thou wast the prettiest Babe that ere I nurst, and I might liue to ſee thee married once, I haue my wish. Old La. Marry that marry is the very theame I came to talke of, tell me daughter Iuliet, How ſtands your disposition to be Married?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SPEECH.LINE: It is an houre that I dreame not of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: An houre, were I not thine onely Nurse, I would ſay thou had'st ſuckt wisedome from thy teat. Old La. Well thinke of marriage now, yonger then you Heere in Verona, Ladies of esteeme, Are made already Mothers. By my count I was your Mother, much vpon these yeares That you are now a Maide, thus then in briefe: The valiant Paris ſeekes you for his loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: A man young Lady, Lady, ſuch a man as all the world. Why hee's a man of waxe. Old La. Veronas Summer hath not ſuch a flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay hee's a flower, infaith a very flower.
Old La.
What ſay you, can you loue the Gentleman?
This night you ſhall behold him at our Feast,
Read ore the volume of young Paris face,
And find delight, writ there with Beauties pen:
Examine euery ſeuerall liniament,
And ſee how one another lends content:
And what obscur’d in this faire volume lies,
Find written in the Margent of his eyes.
This precious Booke of Loue, this vnbound Louer,
To Beautifie him, onely lacks a Couer.
The fish liues in the Sea, and ‘tis much pride
For faire without, the faire within to hide:
That Booke in manies eyes doth ſhare the glorie,
That in Gold claspes, Lockes in the Golden ſtorie:
So ſhall you ſhare all that he doth poſſeſſe,
By hauing him, making your ſelfe no leſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: No leſſe, nay bigger: women grow by men.
Old La.
Speake briefly, can you like of Paris loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile looke to like, if looking liking moue.
But no more deepe will I endart mine eye,
Then your consent giues ſtrength to make flye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, the guests are come, ſupper ſeru’d vp, you cal’d, my young Lady askt for, the Nurse cur'st in the Pan-tery, and euery thing in extremitie: I must hence to wait, I beseech you follow ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: We follow thee, Iuliet, the Countie ſtaies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe Gyrle, ſeeke happie nights to happy daies.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Romeo, Mercutio, Benuolio, with fiue or ſixe other Maskers, Torch-bearers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall this ſpech be ſpoke for our excuse?
Or ſhall we on without Apologie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: The date is out of ſuch prolixitie,
Weele haue no Cupid, hood winkt with a ſkarfe,
Bearing a Tartars painted Bow of lath,
Skaring the Ladies like a Crow-keeper.
But let them measure vs by what they will,
Weele measure them with a Measure, and be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me a Torch, I am not for this ambling.
Being but heauy I will beare the light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay gentle Romeo, we must haue you dance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I beleeue me, you haue dancing ſhoœs
With nimble ſoles, I haue a ſoale of Lead
So ſtakes me to the ground, I cannot moue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a Louer, borrow Cupids wings,
And ſoare with them aboue a common bound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I am too ſore enpearced with his ſhaft,
To ſoare with his light feathers, and to bound:
I cannot bound a pitch aboue dull wœ,
Vnder loues heauy burthen doe I ſinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: And to ſinke in it ſhould you burthen loue,
Too great oppreſſion for a tender thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Is loue a tender thing? it is too rough,
Too rude, too boysterous, and it pricks like thorne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: If loue be rough with you, be rough with loue,
Pricke loue for pricking, and you beat loue downe,
Giue me a Case to put my visage in,
A Visor for a Visor, what care I
What curious eye doth quote deformities:
Here are the Beetle-browes ſhall blush for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Come knocke and enter, and no ſooner in,
But euery man betake him to his legs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: A Torch for me, let wantons light of heart
Tickle the ſenceleſſe rushes with their heeles:
For I am prouerb’d with a Grandsier Phrase,
Ile be a Candle-holder and looke on,
The game was nere ſo faire, and I am done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, duns the Mouse, the Constables owne word,
If thou art dun, weele draw thee from the mire.
Or ſaue your reuerence loue, wherein thou ſtickest
Vp to the eares, come we burne day-light ho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay that’s not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane ſir I delay,
We wast our lights in vaine, lights, lights, by day;
Take our good meaning, for our Iudgement ſits
Fiue times in that, ere once in our fiue wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: And we meane well in going to this Maske,
But ‘tis no wit to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Why may one aske?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I dreampt a dreame to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo did I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Well what was yours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: That dreamers often lye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: In bed a ſleepe while they do dreame things true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: O then I ſee Queene Mab hath beene with you: She is the Fairies Midwife, & ſhe comes in ſhape no big-ger then Agat-stone, on the fore-finger of an Alderman, drawne with a teeme of little Atomies, ouer mens noses as they lie asleepe: her Waggon Spokes made of long Spin-ners legs: the Couer of the wings of Grashoppers, her Traces of the ſmallest Spiders web, her coullers of the Moonshines watry Beames, her Whip of Crickets bone, the Lash of Philome, her Waggoner, a ſmall gray-coated Gnat, not halfe ſo bigge as a round little Worme, prickt from the Lazie-finger of a man. Her Chariot is an emptie Haselnut, made by the Ioyner Squirrel or old Grub, time out a mind, the Faries Coach-makers: & in this ſtate ſhe gallops night by night, through Louers braines: and then they dreame of Loue. On Courtiers knees, that dreame on Cursies ſtrait: ore Lawyers fingers, who ſtrait dreampt on Fees, ore Ladies lips, who ſtrait on kiſſes dreame, which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues, because their breath with Sweet meats tainted are. Sometime ſhe gal-lops ore a Courtiers nose, & then dreames he of ſmelling out a ſute: & ſomtime comes ſhe with Tith pigs tale, tick-ling a Parsons nose as a lies asleepe, then he dreames of another Benefice. Sometime ſhe driueth ore a Souldiers necke, & then dreames he of cutting Forraine throats, of Breaches, Ambuscados, Spanish Blades: Of Healths fiue Fadome deepe, and then anon drums in his eares, at which he ſtartes and wakes; and being thus frighted, ſweares a prayer or two & ſleepes againe: this is that very Mab that plats the manes of Horses in the night: & bakes the Elk-locks in foule ſluttish haires, which once vntangled, much misfortune bodes, This is the hag, when Maides lie on their backs, That preſſes them, and learnes them first to beare, Making them women of good carriage: This is ſhe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace, Mercutio peace,
Thou talk'st of nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: True, I talke of dreames:
Which are the children of an idle braine,
Begot of nothing, but vaine phantasie,
Which is as thin of ſubstance as the ayre,
And more inconstant then the wind, who woœs
Euen now the frozen bosome of the North:
And being anger’d, puffes away from thence,
Turning his ſide to the dew dropping South.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: This wind you talke of blowes vs from our ſelues,
Supper is done, and we ſhall come too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I feare too early, for my mind misgiues,
Some consequence yet hanging in the ſtarres,
Shall bitterly begin his fearefull date
With this nights reuels, and expire the tearme
Of a despised life clos’d in my brest:
By ſome vile forfeit of vntimely death.
But he that hath the ſtirrage of my course,
Direct my ſute: on lustie Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Strike Drum.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: They march about the Stage, and Seruingmen come forth with their napkins

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Where's Potpan, that he helpes not to take away?
He ſhift a Trencher? he ſcrape a Trencher?
When good manners, ſhall lie in one or two mens hands, and they vnwasht too, ‘tis a foule thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Away with the Ioynstooles, remoue the Court-cubbord, looke to the Plate: good thou, ſaue mee a piece of Marchpane, and as thou louest me, let the Porter let in Susan Grindstone, and Nell, Anthonie and Potpan.
I Boy readie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: You are lookt for, and cal’d for, askt for, & ſought for, in the great Chamber.
We cannot be here and there too, chearly Boyes,
Be brisk awhile, and the longer liuer take all.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter all the Guests and Gentlewomen to the Maskers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1. Capu.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome Gentlemen,
Ladies that haue their tœs
Vnplagu’d with Cornes, will walke about with you:
Ah my Mistreſſes, which of you all
Will now deny to dance? She that makes dainty,
She Ile ſweare hath Cornes: am I come neare ye now?
Welcome Gentlemen, I haue ſeene the day
That I haue worne a Visor, and could tell
A whispering tale in a faire Ladies eare:
Such as would please: ‘tis gone, ‘tis gone, ‘tis gone,
You are welcome Gentlemen, come Musitians play:
A Hall, Hall, giue roome, and foote it Girles,
More light you knaues, and turne the Tables vp:
And quench the fire, the Roome is growne too hot.
Ah ſirrah, this vnlookt for ſport comes well:
Nay ſit, nay ſit, good Cozin Capulet,
For you and I are past our dauncing daies:
How long 'ist now ſince last your ſelfe and I
Were in a Maske?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2. Capu.
SPEECH.LINE: Berlady thirty yeares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1. Capu.
SPEECH.LINE: What man: ‘tis not ſo much, ‘tis not ſo much,
‘Tis ſince the Nuptiall of Lucentio,
Come Pentycost as quickely as it will,
Some fiue and twenty yeares, and then we Maskt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2. Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis more, ‘tis more, his Sonne is elder ſir:
His Sonne is thirty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3. Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you tell me that?
His Sonne was but a Ward two yeares agœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: What Ladie is that which doth inrich the hand
Of yonder Knight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſhe doth teach the Torches to burne bright:
It ſeemes ſhe hangs vpon the cheeke of night,
As a rich Iewel in an Aethiops eare:
Beauty too rich for vse, for earth too deare:
So ſhewes a Snowy Doue trooping with Crowes,
As yonder Lady ore her fellowes ſhowes;
The measure done, Ile watch her place of ſtand,
And touching hers, make bleſſed my rude hand.
Did my heart loue till now, forsweare it ſight,
For I neuer ſaw true Beauty till this night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: This by his voice, ſhould be a Mountague.
Fetch me my Rapier Boy, what dares the ſlaue
Come hither couer’d with an antique face,
To fleere and ſcorne at our Solemnitie?
Now by the ſtocke and Honour of my kin,
To ſtrike him dead I hold it not a ſin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now kinsman,
Wherefore ſtorme you ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: Vncle this is a Mountague, our fœ:
A Villaine that is hither come in ſpight,
To ſcorne at our Solemnitie this night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Young Romeo is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis he, that Villaine Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Content thee gentle Coz, let him alone,
A beares him like a portly Gentleman:
And to ſay truth, Verona brags of him,
To be a vertuous and well gouern’d youth:
I would not for the wealth of all the towne,
Here in my house do him disparagement:
Therfore be patient, take no note of him,
It is my will, the which if thou respect,
Shew a faire presence, and put off these frownes,
An ill beseeming ſemblance for a Feast

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: It fits when ſuch a Villaine is a guest,
Ile not endure him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall be endur’d.
What goodman boy, I ſay he ſhall, go too,
Am I the Maister here or you? go too,
Youle not endure him, God ſhall mend my ſoule,
Youle make a Mutinie among the Guests:
You will ſet cocke a hoope, youle be the man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Vncle, ‘tis a ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too, go too,
You are a ſawcy Boy, 'ist ſo indeed?
This tricke may chance to ſcath you, I know what,
You must contrary me, marry ‘tis time.
Well ſaid my hearts, you are a Princox, goe,
Be quiet, or more light, more light for ſhame,
Ile make you quiet. What, chearely my hearts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: Patience perforce, with wilfull choler meeting,
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting:
I will withdraw, but this intrusion ſhall
Now ſeeming ſweet, conuert to bitter gall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: If I prophane with my vnworthiest hand,
This holy ſhrine, the gentle ſin is this,
My lips to blushing Pilgrims did ready ſtand,
To ſmooth that rough touch, with a tender kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Pilgrime,
You do wrong your hand too much.
Which mannerly deuotion ſhewes in this,
For Saints haue hands, that Pilgrims hands do tuch,
And palme to palme, is holy Palmers kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue not Saints lips, and holy Palmers too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I Pilgrim, lips that they must vse in prayer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: O then deare Saint, let lips do what hands do,
They pray (grant thou) least faith turne to dispaire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Saints do not moue,
Though grant for prayers ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Then moue not while my prayers effect I take:
Thus from my lips, by thine my ſin is purg’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Then haue my lips the ſin that they haue tooke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Sin from my lips? O trespaſſe ſweetly vrg’d:
Giue me my ſin againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: You kiſſe by'th’ booke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam your Mother craues a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: What is her Mother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurs.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie Batcheler,
Her Mother is the Lady of the house,
And a good Lady, and a wise, and Vertuous,
I Nur'st her Daughter that you talkt withall:
I tell you, he that can lay hold of her,
Shall haue the chincks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhe a Capulet?
O deare account! My life is my fœs debt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, be gone, the ſport is at the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſo I feare, the more is my vnrest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Gentlemen prepare not to be gone,
We haue a trifling foolish Banquet towards:
Is it e'ne ſo? why then I thanke you all.
I thanke you honeſt Gentlemen, good night:
More Torches here: come on, then let's to bed.
Ah ſirrah, by my faie it waxes late,
Ile to my rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither Nurse,
What is yond Gentleman:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: The Sonne and Heire of old Tyberio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he that now is going out of doore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie that I thinke be young Petruchio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he that follows here that would not dance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Go aske his name: if he be married,
My graue is like to be my wedded bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: His name is Romeo, and a Mountague,
The onely Sonne of your great Enemie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: My onely Loue ſprung from my onely hate,
Too early ſeene, vnknowne, and knowne too late,
Prodigious birth of Loue it is to me,
That I must loue a loathed Enemie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: What's this? whats this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: A rime, I learne euen now
Of one I dan'st withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon:
Come let's away, the ſtrangers all are gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SPEECH.LINE: Now old desire doth in his death bed lie,
And yong affection gapes to be his Heire,
That faire, for which Loue gron’d for and would die,
With tender Iuliet matcht, is now not faire.
Now Romeo is beloued, and Loues againe,
A like bewitched by the charme of lookes:
But to his fœ ſuppos’d he must complaine,
And ſhe ſteale Loues ſweet bait from fearefull hookes:
Being held a fœ, he may not haue acceſſe
To breath ſuch vowes as Louers vse to ſweare,
And ſhe as much in Loue, her meanes much leſſe,
To meete her new Beloued any where:
But paſſion lends them Power, time, meanes to meete,
Temp'ring extremities with extreame ſweete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Can I goe forward when my heart is here?
Turne backe dull earth, and find thy Center out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo, my Cozen Romeo, Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Merc.
SPEECH.LINE: He is wise,
And on my life hath ſtolne him home to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: He ran this way and leapt this Orchard wall.
Call good Mercutio:
Nay, Ile coniure too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo, Humours, Madman, Paſſion, Louer,
Appeare thou in the likeneſſe of a ſigh,
Speake but one time, and I am ſatisfied:
Cry me but ay me, Prouant, but Loue and day,
Speake to my goship Venus one faire word,
One Nickname for her purblind Sonne and her,
Young Abraham Cupid he that ſhot ſo true,
When King Cophetua lou’d the begger Maid,
He heareth not, he ſtirreth not, he moueth not,
The Ape is dead, I must coniure him,
I coniure thee by Rosalines bright eyes,
By her High forehead, and her Scarlet lip,
By her Fine foote, Straight leg, and Quiuering thigh,
And the Demeanes, that there Adiacent lie,
That in thy likeneſſe thou appeare to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: And if he heare thee thou wilt anger him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: This cannot anger him, t'would anger him
To raise a ſpirit in his Mistreſſe circle,
Of ſome ſtrange nature, letting it ſtand
Till ſhe had laid it, and coniured it downe,
That were ſome ſpight.
My inuocation is faire and honeſt, & in his Mistris name,
I coniure onely but to raise vp him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, he hath hid himselfe among these Trees
To be consorted with the Humerous night:
Blind is his Loue, and best befits the darke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: If Loue be blind, Loue cannot hit the marke,
Now will he ſit vnder a Medler tree,
And wish his Mistreſſe were that kind of Fruite,
As Maides cal Medlers when they laugh alone,
O Romeo that ſhe were, O that ſhe were
An open, or thou a Poprin Peare,
Romeo goodnight, Ile to my Truckle bed,
This Field-bed is to cold for me to ſleepe,
Come ſhall we go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Go then, for ‘tis in vaine to ſeeke him here
That meanes not to be found.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: He ieasts at Scarres that neuer felt a wound,
But ſoft, what light through yonder window breaks?
It is the East, and Iuliet is the Sunne,
Arise faire Sun and kill the enuious Moone,
Who is already ſicke and pale with griefe,
That thou her Maid art far more faire then ſhe:
Be not her Maid ſince ſhe is enuious,
Her Vestal liuery is but ſicke and greene,
And none but fooles do weare it, cast it off:
It is my Lady, O it is my Loue, O that ſhe knew ſhe were,
She ſpeakes, yet ſhe ſayes nothing, what of that?
Her eye discourses, I will answere it:
I am too bold ‘tis not to me ſhe ſpeakes:
Two of the fairest ſtarres in all the Heauen,
Hauing ſome busineſſe do entreat her eyes,
To twinckle in their Spheres till they returne.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head,
The brightneſſe of her cheeke would ſhame those ſtarres,
As day-light doth a Lampe, her eye in heauen,
Would through the ayrie Region ſtreame ſo bright,
That Birds would ſing, and thinke it were not night:
See how ſhe leanes her cheeke vpon her hand.
O that I were a Gloue vpon that hand,
That I might touch that cheeke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſpeakes.
Oh ſpeake againe bright Angell, for thou art
As glorious to this night being ore my head,
As is a winged meſſenger of heauen
Vnto the white vpturned wondring eyes
Of mortalls that fall backe to gaze on him,
When he bestrides the lazie puffing Cloudes,
And ſailes vpon the bosome of the ayre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?
Denie thy Father and refuse thy name:
Or if thou wilt not, be but ſworne to my Loue,
And Ile no longer be a Capulet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I heare more, or ſhall I ſpeake at this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis but thy name that is my Enemy:
Thou art thy ſelfe, though not a Mountague,
What's Mountague? it is nor hand nor foote,
Nor arme, nor face, O be ſome other name
Belonging to a man.
What? in a names that which we call a Rose,
By any other word would ſmell as ſweete,
So Romeo would, were he not Romeo cal’d,
Retaine that deare perfection which he owes,
Without that title Romeo, doffe thy name,
And for thy name which is no part of thee,
Take all my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I take thee at thy word:
Call me but Loue, and Ile be new baptiz’d,
Hence foorth I neuer will be Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SPEECH.LINE: What man art thou, that thus bescreen’d in night
So ſtumblest on my counsell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: By a name,
I know not how to tell thee who I am:
My name deare Saint, is hatefull to my ſelfe,
Because it is an Enemy to thee,
Had I it written, I would teare the word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SPEECH.LINE: My eares haue yet not drunke a hundred words
Of thy tongues vttering, yet I know the ſound.
Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither faire Maid, if either thee dislike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: How cam'st thou hither.
Tell me, and wherefore?
The Orchard walls are high, and hard to climbe,
And the place death, considering who thou art,
If any of my kinsmen find thee here,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: With Loues light wings
Did I ore-perch these Walls,
For ſtony limits cannot hold Loue out,
And what Loue can do, that dares Loue attempt:
Therefore thy kinsmen are no ſtop to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: If they do ſee thee, they will murther thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke there lies more perill in thine eye,
Then twenty of their Swords, looke thou but ſweete,
And I am proofe against their enmity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I would not for the world they ſaw thee here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue nights cloake to hide me from their eyes
And but thou loue me, let them finde me here,
My life were better ended by their hate,
Then death proroged wanting of thy Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: By whose direction found'st thou out this place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: By Loue that first did prompt me to enquire,
He lent me counsell, and I lent him eyes,
I am no Pylot, yet wert thou as far
As that vast-shore-washet with the farthest Sea,
I ſhould aduenture for ſuch Marchandise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou knowest the maske of night is on my face,
Else would a Maiden blush bepaint my cheeke,
For that which thou hast heard me ſpeake to night,
Faine would I dwell on forme, faine, faine, denie
What I haue ſpoke, but farewell Complement,
Doest thou Loue? I know thou wilt ſay I,
And I will take thy word, yet if thou ſwear'st,
Thou maiest proue false: at Louers periuries
They ſay Ioue laught, oh gentle Romeo,
If thou dost Loue, pronounce it faithfully:
Or if thou thinkest I am too quickly wonne,
Ile frowne and be peruerse, and ſay thee nay,
So thou wilt woœ: But else not for the world.
In truth faire Mountague I am too fond:
And therefore thou maiest thinke my behauiour light,
But trust me Gentleman, Ile proue more true,
Then those that haue coying to be ſtrange,
I ſhould haue beene more ſtrange, I must confeſſe,
But that thou ouer heard'st ere I was ware
My true Loues paſſion, therefore pardon me,
And not impute this yeelding to light Loue,
Which the darke night hath ſo discouered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Lady, by yonder Moone I vow,
That tips with ſiluer all these Fruite tree tops.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſweare not by the Moone, th’ inconstant Moone,
That monethly changes in her circled Orbe,
Least that thy Loue proue likewise variable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall I ſweare by?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not ſweare at all:
Or if thou wilt ſweare by thy gratious ſelfe,
Which is the God of my Idolatry,
And Ile beleeue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: If my hearts deare loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SPEECH.LINE: Well do not ſweare, although I ioy in thee:
I haue no ioy of this contract to night,
It is too rash, too vnaduis’d, too ſudden,
Too like the lightning which doth cease to be
Ere, one can ſay, it lightens, Sweete good night:
This bud of Loue by Summers ripening breath,
May proue a beautious Flower when next we meete:
Goodnight, goodnight, as ſweete repose and rest,
Come to thy heart, as that within my brest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: O wilt thou leaue me ſo vnsatisfied?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſatisfaction can'st thou haue to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: Th’ exchange of thy Loues faithfull vow for mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I gaue thee mine before thou did'st request it:
And yet I would it were to giue againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Would'st thou withdraw it,
For what purpose Loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: But to be franke and giue it thee againe,
And yet I wish but for the thing I haue,
My bounty is as boundleſſe as the Sea,
My Loue as deepe, the more I giue to thee
The more I haue, for both are Infinite:
I heare ſome noyse within deare Loue adue:
Anon good Nurse, ſweet Mountague be true:
Stay but a little, I will come againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: O bleſſed bleſſed night, I am afear’d
Being in night, all this is but a dreame,
Too flattering ſweet to be ſubstantiall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Three words deare Romeo,
And goodnight indeed,
If that thy bent of Loue be Honourable,
Thy purpose marriage, ſend me word to morrow,
By one that Ile procure to come to thee,
Where and what time thou wilt performe the right,
And all my Fortunes at thy foote Ile lay,
And follow thee my Lord throughout the world.
Within:
Madam.
I come, anon: but if thou meanest not well,
I do beseech thee
Within:
Madam.
(By and by I come)
To cease thy ſtrife, and leaue me to my griefe,
To morrow will I ſend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: So thriue my ſoule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu
SPEECH.LINE: A thousand times goodnight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rome.
SPEECH.LINE: A thousand times the worse to want thy light,
Loue goes toward Loue as ſchool-boyes fro[m] their books
But Loue fro[m] Loue, towards ſchoole with heauie lookes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Hist Romeo hist: O for a Falkners voice,
To lure this Taſſell gentle backe againe,
Bondage is hoarse, and may not ſpeake aloud,
Else would I teare the Caue where Eccho lies,
And make her ayrie tongue more hoarse, then
With repetition of my Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: It is my ſoule that calls vpon my name.
How ſiluer ſweet, ſound Louers tongues by night,
Like ſoftest Musicke to attending eares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: My Neece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: What a clock to morrow
Shall I ſend to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: By the houre of nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not faile, ‘tis twenty yeares till then,
I haue forgot why I did call thee backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſtand here till thou remember it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall forget, to haue thee ſtill ſtand there,
Remembring how I Loue thy company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: And Ile ſtill ſtay, to haue thee ſtill forget,
Forgetting any other home but this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis almost morning, I would haue thee gone,
And yet no further then a wantons Bird,
That let's it hop a little from his hand,
Like a poore prisoner in his twisted Gyues,
And with a ſilken thred plucks it backe againe,
So louing Iealous of his liberty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I were thy Bird.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet ſo would I,
Yet I ſhould kill thee with much cherishing:
Good night, good night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Parting is ſuch ſweete ſorrow,
That I ſhall ſay goodnight, till it be morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Sleepe dwell vpon thine eyes, peace in thy brest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I were ſleepe and peace ſo ſweet to rest,
The gray ey’d morne ſmiles on the frowning night,
Checkring the Easterne Clouds with ſtreakes of light,
And darkeneſſe fleckel’d like a drunkard reeles,
From forth dayes pathway, made by Titans wheeles.
Hence will I to my ghostly Friers close Cell,
His helpe to craue, and my deare hap to tell.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Frier alone with a basket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: The gray ey’d morne ſmiles on the frowning night,
Checkring the Easterne Cloudes with ſtreaks of light:
And fleckled darkneſſe like a drunkard reeles,
From forth daies path, and Titans burning wheeles:
Now ere the Sun aduance his burning eye,
The day to cheere, and nights danke dew to dry,
I must vpfill this Osier Cage of ours,
With balefull weedes, and precious Iuiced flowers,
The earth that’s Natures mother, is her Tombe,
What is her burying graue that is her wombe:
And from her wombe children of diuers kind
We ſucking on her naturall bosome find:
Many for many vertues excellent:
None but for ſome, and yet all different.
O mickle is the powerfull grace that lies
In Plants, Hearbs, ſtones, and their true qualities:
For nought ſo vile, that on earth doth liue,
But to the earth ſome ſpeciall good doth giue.
Nor ought ſo good, but ſtrain’d from that faire vse,
Reuolts from true birth, ſtumbling on abuse.
Vertue it ſelfe turnes vice being misapplied,
And vice ſometime by action dignified.
Within the infant rind of this weake flower,
Poyson hath residence, and medicine power:
For this being ſmelt, with that part cheares each part,
Being tasted ſtayes all ſences with the heart.
Two ſuch opposed Kings encampe them ſtill,
In man as well as Hearbes, grace and rude will:
And where the worser is predominant,
Full ſoone the Canker death eates vp that Plant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Benedecite.
What early tongue ſo ſweet ſaluteth me?
Young Sonne, it argues a distempered head,
So ſoone to bid goodmorrow to thy bed;
Care keepes his watch in euery old mans eye,
And where Care lodges, ſleepe will neuer lye:
But where vnbrused youth with vnstuft braine
Doth couch his lims, there, golden ſleepe doth raigne;
Therefore thy earlineſſe doth me aſſure,
Thou art vprous’d with ſome distemprature;
Or if not ſo, then here I hit it right.
Our Romeo hath not beene in bed to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: That last is true, the ſweeter rest was mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: God pardon ſin: wast thou with Rosaline?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: With Rosaline, my ghostly Father? No,
I haue forgot that name, and that names wœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: That's my good Son, but wher hast thou bin then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile tell thee ere thou aske it me agen:
I haue beene feasting with mine enemie,
Where on a ſudden one hath wounded me,
That's by me wounded: both our remedies
Within thy helpe and holy phisicke lies:
I beare no hatred, bleſſed man: for lœ
My interceſſion likewise ſteads my fœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Be plaine good Son, rest homely in thy drift,
Ridling confeſſion, findes but ridling ſhrift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Then plainly know my hearts deare Loue is ſet,
On the faire daughter of rich Capulet:
As mine on hers, ſo hers is ſet on mine;
And all combin’d, ſaue what thou must combine
By holy marriage: when and where, and how,
We met, we woœd, and made exchange of vow:
Ile tell thee as we paſſe, but this I pray,
That thou consent to marrie vs to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Holy S[aint]. Francis, what a change is heere?
Is Rosaline that thou didst Loue ſo deare
So ſoone forsaken? young mens Loue then lies
Not truely in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Iesu Maria, what a deale of brine
Hath washt thy ſallow cheekes for Rosaline?
How much ſalt water throwne away in wast,
To ſeason Loue that of it doth not tast.
The Sun not yet thy ſighes, from heauen cleares,
Thy old grones yet ringing in my auncient eares:
Lo here vpon thy cheeke the ſtaine doth ſit,
Of an old teare that is not washt off yet.
If ere thou wast thy ſelfe, and these wœs thine,
Thou and these wœs, were all for Rosaline.
And art thou chang’d? pronounce this ſentence then,
Women may fall, when there's no ſtrength in men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou chid'st me oft for louing Rosaline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: For doting, not for louing pupill mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: And bad'st me bury Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Not in a graue,
To lay one in, another out to haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee chide me not, her I Loue now
Doth grace for grace, and Loue for Loue allow:
The other did not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſhe knew well,
Thy Loue did read by rote, that could not ſpell:
But come young wauerer, come goe with me,
In one respect, Ile thy aſſistant be:
For this alliance may ſo happy proue,
To turne your houshould rancor to pure Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: O let vs hence, I ſtand on ſudden hast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Wisely and ſlow, they ſtumble that run fast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Where the deule ſhould this Romeo be? came he not home to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Not to his Fathers, I ſpoke with his man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that ſame pale hard-harted wench, that Ro-saline torments him ſo, that he will ſure run mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Tibalt, the kinsman to old Capulet, hath ſent a Let-ter to his Fathers house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: A challenge on my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo will answere it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Any man that can write, may answere a Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, he will answere the Letters Maister how he dares, being dared.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas poore Romeo, he is already dead ſtab’d with a white wenches blacke eye, runne through the eare with a Loue ſong, the very pinne of his heart, cleft with the blind Bowe-boyes but-shaft, and is he a man to encounter Tybalt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Why what is Tibalt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: More then Prince of Cats. Oh hee's the Couragi-ous Captaine of Complements: he fights as you ſing pricksong, keeps time, distance, and proportion, he rests his minum, one, two, and the third in your bosom: the ve-ry butcher of a ſilk button, a Dualist, a Dualist: a Gentleman of the very first house of the first and ſecond cause: ah the immortall Paſſado, the Punto reuerso, the Hay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: The what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: The Pox of ſuch antique lisping affecting phan-tacies, these new tuners of accent: Iesu a very good blade, a very tall man, a very good whore. Why is not this a la-mentable thing Grandsire, that we ſhould be thus afflicted with these ſtrange flies: these fashion Mongers, these par-don-mee's, who ſtand ſo much on the new form, that they cannot ſit at ease on the old bench. O their bones, their bones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Without his Rœ, like a dryed Hering. O flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified? Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in: Laura to his Lady, was a kitchen wench, marrie ſhe had a better Loue to berime her: Dido a dowdie, Cleopatra a Gipsie, Hellen and Hero, hildings and Harlots: Thisbie a gray eie or ſo, but not to the purpose. Signior Romeo, Bon iour, there's a French ſalutation to your French ſlop: you gaue vs the counterfait fairely last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Romeo.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow to you both, what counterfeit did I giue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſlip ſir, the ſlip, can you not conceiue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon Mercutio, my busineſſe was great, and in ſuch a case as mine, a man may ſtraine curtesie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: That's as much as to ſay, ſuch a case as yours con-strains a man to bow in the hams.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Meaning to cursie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast mo’t kindly hit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t curteous exposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I am the very pinck of curtesie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Pinke for flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then is my Pump well flowr’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Sure wit, follow me this ieast, now till thou hast worne out thy Pump, that when the ſingle ſole of it is worne, the ieast may remaine after the wearing, ſole-singular. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſingle ſol’d ieast,
Soly ſingular for the ſingleneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Come betweene vs good Benuolio, my wits faints.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Swits and ſpurs,
Swits and ſpurs, or Ile crie a match.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if our wits run the Wild-Goose chase, I am done: For thou hast more of the Wild-Goose in one of thy wits, then I am ſure I haue in my whole fiue. Was I with you there for the Goose?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wast neuer with mee for any thing, when thou wast not there for the Goose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: I will bite thee by the eare for that iest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good Goose bite not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy wit is a very Bitter-sweeting,
It is a mo’t ſharpe ſawce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: And is it not well ſeru’d into a Sweet-Goose?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh here's a wit of Cheuerell, that ſtretches from an ynch narrow, to an ell broad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſtretch it out for that word, broad, which added to the Goose, proues thee farre and wide, abroad Goose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Why is not this better now, then groning for Loue, now art thou ſociable, now art thou Romeo: now art thou what thou art, by Art as well as by Nature, for this driueling Loue is like a great Naturall, that runs lolling vp and downe to hid his bable in a hole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Stop there, ſtop there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou desir'st me to ſtop in my tale against the haire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou would'st else haue made thy tale large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: O thou art deceiu’d, I would haue made it ſhort, or I was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant indeed to occupie the argument no longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's a goodly geare.
A ſayle, a ſayle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Two, two: a Shirt and a Smocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Peter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: My Fan Peter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Peter to hide her face?
For her Fans the fairer face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: God ye good morrow Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: God ye gooden faire Gentlewoman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it gooden?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis no leſſe I tell you: for the bawdy hand of the
Dyall is now vpon the pricke of Noone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Out vpon you: what a man are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: One Gentlewoman,
That God hath made, himselfe to mar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth it is ſaid, for himselfe to, mar qua-tha: Gentlemen, can any of you tel me where I may find the young Romeo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Romeo.
SPEECH.LINE: I can tell you: but young Romeo will be older when you haue found him, then he was when you ſought him: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſay well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea is the worst well,
Very well tooke: Ifaith, wisely, wisely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: If you be he ſir,
I desire ſome confidence with you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: She will endite him to ſome Supper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: A baud, a baud, a baud. So ho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: What hast thou found?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: No Hare ſir, vnleſſe a Hare ſir in a Lenten pie, that is ſomething ſtale and hoare ere it be ſpent. An old Hare hoare, and an old Hare hoare is very good meat in Lent. But a Hare that is hoare is too much for a ſcore, when it hoares ere it be ſpent, Romeo will you come to your Fathers? Weele to dinner thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I will follow you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell auncient Lady:
Farewell Lady, Lady, Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you ſir, what ſawcie Merchant was this that was ſo full of his roperie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: A Gentleman Nurse, that loues to heare himselfe talke, and will ſpeake more in a minute, then he will ſtand to in a Moneth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: And a ſpeake any thing against me, Ile take him downe, z a were lustier then he is, and twentie ſuch Iacks: and if I cannot, Ile finde those that ſhall: ſcuruie knaue, I am none of his flurt-gils, I am none of his ſkaines mates, and thou must ſtand by too and ſuffer euery knaue to vse me at his pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſaw no man vse you at his pleasure: if I had, my weapon ſhould quickly haue beene out, I warrant you, I dare draw aſſoone as another man, if I ſee occasion in a good quarrell, and the law on my ſide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Now afore God, I am ſo vext, that euery part about me quiuers, ſkuruy knaue: pray you ſir a word: and as I told you, my young Lady bid me enquire you out, what ſhe bid me ſay, I will keepe to my ſelfe: but first let me tell ye, if ye ſhould leade her in a fooles paradise, as they ſay, it were a very groſſe kind of behauiour, as they ſay: for the Gentlewoman is yong: & therefore, if you ſhould deale double with her, truely it were an ill thing to be of-fered to any Gentlewoman, and very weake dealing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Nurse commend me to thy Lady and Mistreſſe, I protest vnto thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Good heart, and yfaith I will tell her as much:
Lord, Lord ſhe will be a ioyfull woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: What wilt thou tell her Nurse? thou doest not marke me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell her ſir, that you do protest, which as I take it, is a Gentleman-like offer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Bid her deuise ſome meanes to come to ſhrift this afternoone,
And there ſhe ſhall at Frier Lawrence Cell
Be ſhriu’d and married: here is for thy paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: No truly ſir not a penny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too, I ſay you ſhall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: This afternoone ſir? well ſhe ſhall be there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſtay thou good Nurse behind the Abbey wall,
Within this houre my man ſhall be with thee,
And bring thee Cords made like a tackled ſtaire,
Which to the high top gallant of my ioy,
Must be my conuoy in the ſecret night.
Farewell, be trustie and Ile quite thy paines:
Farewell, commend me to thy Mistreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Now God in heauen bleſſe thee: harke you ſir,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaist thou my deare Nurse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SPEECH.LINE: Is your man ſecret, did you nere heare ſay two may keepe counsell putting one away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: Warrant thee my man is true as ſteele.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, my Mistreſſe is the ſweetest Lady, Lord, Lord, when 'twas a little prating thing. O there is a No-ble man in Towne one Paris, that would faine lay knife a-board: but ſhe good ſoule had as leeue ſee a Toade, a very Toade as ſee him: I anger her ſometimes, and tell her that Paris is the properer man, but Ile warrant you, when I ſay ſo, ſhee lookes as pale as any clout in the versall world. Doth not Rosemarie and Romeo begin both with a letter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I Nurse, what of that? Both with an R

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: A mocker that’s the dogs name. R. is for the no, I know it begins with ſome other letter, and ſhe hath the prettiest ſententious of it, of you and Rosemary, that it would do you good to heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Commend me to thy Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: I a thousand times. Peter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur
SPEECH.LINE: Before and apace. Exit Nurse and Peter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: The clocke ſtrook nine, when I did ſend the Nurse,
In halfe an houre ſhe promised to returne,
Perchance ſhe cannot meete him: that’s not ſo:
Oh ſhe is lame, Loues Herauld ſhould be thoughts,
Which ten times faster glides then the Sunnes beames,
Driuing backe ſhadowes ouer lowring hils.
Therefore do nimble Pinion’d Doues draw Loue,
And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings:
Now is the Sun vpon the highmost hill
Of this daies iourney, and from nine till twelue,
Is three long houres, yet ſhe is not come.
Had ſhe affections and warme youthfull blood,
She would be as ſwift in motion as a ball,
My words would bandy her to my ſweete Loue,
And his to me, but old folkes,
Many faine as they were dead,
Vnwieldie, ſlow, heauy, and pale as lead.
O God ſhe comes, O hony Nurse what newes?
Hast thou met with him? ſend thy man away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Peter ſtay at the gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good ſweet Nurse:
O Lord, why lookest thou ſad?
Though newes, be ſad, yet tell them merrily.
If good thou ſham'st the musicke of ſweet newes,
By playing it to me, with ſo ſower a face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a weary, giue me leaue awhile,
Fie how my bones ake, what a iaunt haue I had?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I would thou had'st my bones, and I thy newes:
Nay come I pray thee ſpeake, good good Nurse ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Iesu what hast? can you not ſtay a while?
Do you not ſee that I am out of breath?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breth
To ſay to me, that thou art out of breath?
The excuse that thou dost make in this delay,
Is longer then the tale thou dost excuse.
Is thy newes good or bad? answere to that,
Say either, and Ile ſtay the circumstance:
Let me be ſatisfied, ist good or bad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, you haue made a ſimple choice, you know not how to chuse a man: Romeo, no not he though his face be better then any mans, yet his legs excels all mens, and for a hand, and a foote, and a body, though they be not to be talkt on, yet they are past compare: he is not the flower of curtesie, but Ile warrant him as gentle a Lambe: go thy waies wench, ſerue God. What haue you din’d at home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: No no: but all this did I know before
What ſaies he of our marriage? what of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord how my head akes, what a head haue I?
It beates as it would fall in twenty peeces.
My backe a tother ſide: o my backe, my backe:
Beshrew your heart for ſending me about
To catch my death with iaunting vp and downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Ifaith: I am ſorrie that thou art ſo well.
Sweet ſweet, ſweet Nurse, tell me what ſaies my Loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Loue ſaies like an honeſt Gentleman,
And a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome,
And I warrant a vertuous: where is your Mother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is my Mother?
Why ſhe is within, where ſhould ſhe be?
How odly thou repli'st:
Your Loue ſaies like an honeſt Gentleman:
Where is your Mother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: O Gods Lady deare,
Are you ſo hot? marrie come vp I trow,
Is this the Poultis for my aking bones?
Henceforward do your meſſages your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere's ſuch a coile, come what ſaies Romeo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you got leaue to go to ſhift to day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nur.
SPEECH.LINE: Then high you hence to Frier Lawrence Cell,
There ſtaies a Husband to make you a wife:
Now comes the wanton bloud vp in your cheekes,
Thei'le be in Scarlet ſtraight at any newes:
Hie you to Church, I must an other way,
To fetch a Ladder by the which your Loue
Must climde a birds nest Soone when it is darke:
I am the drudge, and toile in your delight:
But you ſhall beare the burthen ſoone at night.
Go Ile to dinner, hie you to the Cell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul
SPEECH.LINE: Hie to high Fortune, honeſt Nurse, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſmile the heauens vpon this holy act,
That after houres, with ſorrow chide vs not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, amen, but come what ſorrow can,
It cannot counteruaile the exchange of ioy
That one ſhort minute giues me in her ſight:
Do thou but close our hands with holy words.
Then Loue-deuouring death do what he dare,
It is inough. I may call her mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: These violent delights haue violent endes,
And in their triumph: die like fire and powder;
Which as they kiſſe consume. The ſweetest honey
Is loathsome in his owne deliciousneſſe,
And in the taste confoundes the appetite.
Therefore Loue moderately, long Loue doth ſo,
Too ſwift arriues as tardie as too ſlow.
Here comes the Lady. Oh ſo light a foot
Will nere weare out the euerlasting flint,
A Louer may bestride the Goſſamours,
That ydles in the wanton Summer ayre,
And yet not fall, ſo light is vanitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Good euen to my ghostly Confeſſor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo ſhall thanke thee Daughter for vs both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: As much to him, else in his thanks too much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah Iuliet, if the measure of thy ioy
Be heapt like mine, and that thy ſkill be more
To blason it, then ſweeten with thy breath
This neighbour ayre, and let rich musickes tongue,
Vnfold the imagin’d happineſſe that both
Receiue in either, by this deere encounter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Conceit more rich in matter then in words,
Brags of his ſubstance, not of Ornament:
They are but beggers that can count their worth,
But my true Loue is growne to ſuch exceſſe,
I cannot ſum vp ſome of halfe my wealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come with me, & we will make ſhort worke,
For by your leaues, you ſhall not ſtay alone,
Till holy Church incorporate two in one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee good Mercutio lets retire, The day is hot, the Capulets abroad: And if we meet, we ſhal not ſcape a brawle, for now these hot dayes, is the mad blood ſtirring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art like one of these fellowes, that when he enters the confines of a Tauerne, claps me his Sword vpon the Table, and ſayes, God ſend me no need of thee: and by the operation of the ſecond cup, drawes him on the Draw-er, when indeed there is no need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I like ſuch a Fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, thou art as hot a Iacke in thy mood, as any in Italie: and aſſoone moued to be moodie, and as-soone moodie to be mou’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: And what too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, and there were two ſuch, we ſhould haue none ſhortly, for one would kill the other: thou, why thou wilt quarrell with a man that hath a haire more, or a haire leſſe in his beard, then thou hast: thou wilt quarrell with a man for cracking Nuts, hauing no other reason, but be-cause thou hast hasell eyes: what eye, but ſuch an eye, would ſpie out ſuch a quarrell? thy head is full of quar-rels, as an egge is full of meat, and yet thy head hath bin beaten as addle as an egge for quarreling: thou hast quar-rel’d with a man for coffing in the ſtreet, because he hath wakened thy Dog that hath laine asleepe in the Sun. Did'st thou not fall out with a Tailor for wearing his new Doub-let before Easter? with another, for tying his new ſhoœs with old Riband, and yet thou wilt Tutor me from quar-relling? _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: And I were ſo apt to quarell as thou art, any man ſhould buy the Fee-simple of my life, for an houre and a quarter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: The Fee-simple? O ſimple.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: By my head here comes the Capulets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: By my heele I care not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tyb.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow me close, for I will ſpeake to them.
Gentlemen, Good den, a word with one of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: And but one word with one of vs? couple it with ſomething, make it a word and a blow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall find me apt inough to that ſir, and you will giue me occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mercu.
SPEECH.LINE: Could you not take ſome occasion without giuing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: Mercutio thou consort'st with Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Consort? what dost thou make vs Minstrels? & thou make Minstrels of vs, looke to heare nothing but dis-cords: heere's my fiddlesticke, heere's that ſhall make you daunce. Come consort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: We talke here in the publike haunt of men,
Either withdraw vnto ſome priuate place,
Or reason coldly of your greeuances:
Or else depart, here all eies gaze on vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Mens eyes were made to looke, and let them gaze.
I will not budge for no mans pleasure I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: Well peace be with you ſir, here comes my man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: But Ile be hang’d ſir if he weare your Liuery.
Marry go before to field, heele be your follower,
Your worship in that ſense, may call him man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo, the loue I beare thee, can affoord
No better terme then this: Thou art a Villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Tibalt, the reason that I haue to loue thee,
Doth much excuse the appertaining rage
To ſuch a greeting: Villaine am I none;
Therefore farewell, I ſee thou know'st me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: Boy, this ſhall not excuse the iniuries
That thou hast done me, therefore turne and draw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I do protest I neuer iniur’d thee,
But lou’d thee better then thou can'st deuise:
Till thou ſhalt know the reason of my loue,
And ſo good Capulet, which name I tender
As dearely as my owne, be ſatisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: O calme, dishonourable, vile ſubmiſſion:
Alla ſtucatho carries it away.
Tybalt, you Rat-catcher, will you walke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: What wouldst thou haue with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Good King of Cats, nothing but one of your nine liues, that I meane to make bold withall, and as you ſhall vse me hereafter dry beate the rest of the eight. Will you pluck your Sword out of his Pilcher by the eares? Make hast, least mine be about your eares ere it be out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tib.
SPEECH.LINE: I am for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle Mercutio, put thy Rapier vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſir, your Paſſado.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Draw Benuolio, beat downe their weapons:
Gentlemen, for ſhame forbeare this outrage,
Tibalt, Mercutio, the Prince expresly hath
Forbidden bandying in Verona ſtreetes.
Hold Tybalt, good Mercutio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: I am hurt.
A plague a both the Houses, I am ſped:
Is he gone and hath nothing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou hurt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I, a ſcratch, a ſcratch, marry ‘tis inough,
Where is my Page? go Villaine fetch a Surgeon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Courage man, the hurt cannot be much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: No: ‘tis not ſo deepe as a well, nor ſo wide as a Church doore, but ‘tis inough, 'twill ſerue: aske for me to morrow, and you ſhall find me a graue man. I am pepper’d I warrant, for this world: a plague a both your houses. What, a Dog, a Rat, a Mouse, a Cat to ſcratch a man to death: a Braggart, a Rogue, a Villaine, that fights by the booke of Arithmeticke, why the deu'le came you be-tweene vs? I was hurt vnder your arme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I thought all for the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe me into ſome house Benuolio,
Or I ſhall faint: a plague a both your houses.
They haue made wormesmeat of me,
I haue it, and ſoundly to your Houses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: This Gentleman the Princes neere Alie,
My very Friend hath got his mortall hurt
In my behalfe, my reputation ſtain’d
With Tibalts ſlaunder, Tybalt that an houre
Hath beene my Cozin: O Sweet Iuliet,
Thy Beauty hath made me Effeminate,
And in my temper ſoftned Valours ſteele.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: O Romeo, Romeo, braue Mercutio's is dead,
That Gallant ſpirit hath aspir’d the Cloudes,
Which too vntimely here did ſcorne the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: This daies blacke Fate, on mo daies depend,
This but begins, the wo others must end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
